Quisiera comentar que la paradoja que plantea el profesor en los primeros 5 minutos, es únicamente paradoja bajo la lógica aristotélica. La derivada, incluso en un punto, es un límite: la tendencia de una función a devolverme un determinado resultado. Si usted considera cualquier cosa (al menos cualquier cosa material) en un determinado instante de tiempo, o en comparación de sus semejantes, debe entender que ese objeto cambia en un instante de tiempo determinado. Siempre ocurre eso. O al menos es sutilmente diferente a sus semejantes (un kilo de azúcar no es igual a otro kilo de azúcar. Tampoco un kilo de azúcar es igual a sí mismo al pasar un valor diferencial de tiempo (la física y la química actúan sobre dicho material)).
Lo que plantea el profesor es verdad en el contexto matemático de abstracción pura de instante T(tiempo)=0. Pero en la realidad, el tiempo nunca se detiene. Nunca T=0. Siempre es continuo. Por lo tanto, afirmar que algo en un instante T=0 posee determinada propiedad es irreal, falso, porque dicho objeto NO EXISTE en T=0. Lo que dice al final, la derivada SÍ ES la proporción de cambio para el diferencial de una variable X porque el diferencial es una situación limite, no un resultado de valuar una función en T=0. Simplemente la matemática no dice que ese es el resultado. Dice que es “el resultado más probable para valores muuuuuuuy cercanos a 0, pero distintos de 0”. Old time mechanical speedometers do not work they way he describes. They do not compute anything. A flexible cable is attached to a small gearbox that is driven by the rotation of the the transmission (ultimately, the wheels). The other end is attached to a small magnetic disk that is rotated by the cable. Next to this is another disk attached to the speedometer needle. The two disks share a common rotation point, like two wheels attached to the same axle. The second disk is spring loaded to hold the needle at zero. As the car speeds up, the magnetized disk spins faster and faster exerting more and more magnetic force on the second disk. That force causes the disk to pull against the restraining spring so it moves. The distance it rotates is related to the magnetic force it experiences, which is a function of the speed at which the magnetized disk rotates, and ultimately, the speed of the car

As a second example, acceleration is the rate that velocity changes and, since force is proportional to acceleration, acceleration must also be well-defined at all instants of time.  A method for determining the value of a rate is not the same as the rate itself.  A rate can have an instantaneous value, in fact, even if it is impossible for us to know what that value is.

To me, nonstandard analysis (an unfortunate and derisive-sounding name to rival that of imaginary numbers) is so much more elegant and intuitive as an (equally rigorous) foundation for calculus that I think it should be the standard introduction; sure, discussion of limits and such is important and needs to be done eventually, but to throw all that intuition out for it is just... heartbreaking. Also, perhaps my perspective has been warped from years of working with calculus, but I'm not sure I agree that an instantaneous rate of change is inherently nonsense. Kinetic energy, for example, is proportional to the square of just such a property (velocity) - and yet kinetic energy is clearly a physical phenomenon. There are tons of examples in the physical sciences of instantaneous rates of change having intrinsic physical meaning. You get back to this at 15:27, but I don't think you've actually struck upon a paradox or mathematical insight - you're just using imprecise language. Is the car moving? Depends on what you mean by moving. If you mean the velocity - the first derivative - then, no, it's not. It's moving on the open interval (0, ∞). In that case, your next question is "when does it start moving?" Again, this could be interpreted in several ways. If you mean "what's the last time at which the car has zero velocity," then the answer is clearly t = 0. If you mean "what's the first time at which the car has nonzero velocity," a very different question, then there's no answer - it's a faulty question. Open intervals on the continuum just don't have a first point. It doesn't start moving at any particular value time, but immediately after t = 0. Alternatively, we could interpret the word "moving" to include acceleration and all higher-order derivatives of position (which is perhaps closer to our intuitive notion of movement), in which case the car is indeed moving at t = 0. None of these interpretations are a paradox. It's just a failure to map imprecise natural language to mathematics.

I disagree with the central contention of this video. Mathematical thinking is all about layers of abstraction. We can make moves at a higher level of abstraction that are impossible/absurd at lower levels to produce a useful answer at a lower level. For instance, there is no such thing as -1 apples in reality (level 0). But at level 1, I can introduce the abstract concept of negative numbers (the level numbering is totally arbitrary; obviously you need several abstractions in play before you can get negatives). Then, by manipulating those negative numbers, I can arrive at useful information about my number of apples in the real world.
To take an example I'm quite fond of, there's no such thing as an imaginary number on level 0. It's an extremely abstract concept. However, when we are on a high enough level of abstraction to sustain imaginary numbers, we can use them to produce imaginary zeroes in a function. Those imaginary zeroes are translatable back into a legitimate concept on level 0, such as an object getting closer to a point and then further from it without reaching it.
In the case of the derivative, we're doing something similar at an even higher level. The concept of the rate of change in position over time at a single point in time is totally absurd in both level 0 and most of the more familiar levels of mathematical abstraction, but we can go to an even higher level of abstraction in which that concept is perfectly legitimate in order to produce results that are translatable back down the levels of abstraction into reality.

The idea of instantaneous rate of change does actually make sense for a slightly modified definition of "instantaneous." Although the rate of change is not a property of a single snapshot of time, it IS a property of a small window of time around the instant no matter how small the window is . This is the sense in which the rate of change is "instantaneous;" if you take any (open) interval of time that includes that instant, no matter how small, the derivative at that instant is fully determined by only that interval. This means that the value of the function at all other times is demonstrably unnecessary to knowing the derivative, just zoom in on an interval of time that cuts off before, or starts up after, the time in question, and you still have enough info to determine the derivative.

At that point, the only piece of information you lose is the direction of motion, since the arrow of time is arbitrary.

To me, conceptually, taking a derivative involves two steps:
1) Look locally at the point in question. That's subtly different (as I'm sure you know) from looking at a snapshot: looking locally means restricting ourselves to asking only questions whose answers are available in every neighborhood of the point in question, no matter how small that neighborhood is, but looking at a "snapshot" would mean looking only at that one particular value.
2) Summarize what you see with a linear approximation. That is, beyond the value of the function at the point in question, we'll be able to see the slope of the approximating line, but no other local data.

The "is the car moving?" paradox is a subtlety around step 2. That is, we can still determine whether the car is moving by looking at local data, but we discarded the answer when we summarized with a linear approximation. (Personally, I'd say "the car is moving at t" should mean "the function is not locally constant at t".) On the other hand, the "derivatives aren't really instantaneous" insight you're trying to convey is about subtlety in step 1. That is, it's about distinguishing between local data and a snapshot. The infinitesimal approach to calculus, formalized by Abraham Robinson in the 1960's, puts on a solid foundation the idea of two quantities being "infinitely close" using an extended number system. It allows for intuition to be developed in a rigorous setting for these ideas, and it simplifies many analysis proofs to merely lines. For instance, a single calculation, rather than an epsilon-delta proof, can show the squaring function to not be uniformly continuous in this approach. There is some work being done into investigating how students think about infinitesimals and "infinitely small" concepts. You can see David Tall's paper "Intuitive infinitesimals in the calculus" for more details if you are interested.
